John Cena, born on December 23, 1977, in West Newbury, Massachusetts, is an American professional wrestler, actor, and rapper. He is best known for his tenure with the WWE (World Wrestling Entertainment) and his role in the evolution of the wrestling industry's athletic and theatrical aspect.

As a teenager, Cena began his professional wrestling career in 1999, debuting in the New England Championship Wrestling (NECW) promotion. Soon after, he caught the attention of WWE and signed with the company in 2001. Cena quickly rose to prominence in the WWE, winning a record 13 world championships, including eight reigns as WWE Champion. He was also a four-time Royal Rumble winner and a one-time United States Champion.

Apart from his wrestling accomplishments, Cena is recognized for his charitable work. He's served as the WWE's spokesperson for the Special Olympics and has raised millions of dollars for various charities through his "WWE All Stars" pay-per-view events.

As an entertainer, Cena has been heavily involved in hip-hop, often incorporating rap into his in-ring promos and releases albums such as "You Can't See Me" and "The Code."

Cena has received numerous accolades throughout his career, including 12-time Slammy Award winner, nine-time WWE Hall of Famer, and a six-time MTV Video Music Award nominee.

With his distinctive flamboyant persona and his ability to adapt and evolve within the wrestling industry, John Cena has become one of the most recognizable and enduring figures in professional wrestling.
